snippet.description:
With the 2012 Christmas Lectures exploring the chemistry of the modern world, we asked some of our friends to choose their favourite chemical element.

Each day in December, we'll publish a new video revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people. 

Featuring, amongst others: Brian Cox, Mark Miodownik, Dick & Dom, Helen Czerski, Dara O Briain, Liz Bonnin and this year's Christmas Lecturer, Dr Peter Wothers. Plus, watch out for some surprise guest appearances.

The Ri is on Twitter: http://twitter.com/ri_science
and Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/royalinstitution
and Tumblr: http://ri-science.tumblr.com/
Our editorial policy: http://www.rigb.org/home/editorial-policy
Subscribe for the latest science videos: http://bit.ly/RiNewsletter
snippet.title: My Favourite Element - Trailer

snippet.description:
Former Christmas Lecturer, Professor Mark Miodownik admits a (healthy) addiction to his favourite element, Oxygen. Making up roughly 21% of the air we breathe, element number eight literally lights our fires and is vital for life on earth.

Each day in December, we'll publish a new video revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people.

and Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/royalinstitution
and Tumblr: http://ri-science.tumblr.com/
Our editorial policy: http://www.rigb.org/home/editorial-policy
Subscribe for the latest science videos: http://bit.ly/RiNewsletter
snippet.title: Mark Miodownik - Addicted to Oxygen

snippet.description:
TV Presenter Liz Bonnin looks to the stars for her pick from the Periodic Table. The properties of Beryllium make it the perfect material for the huge mirror being used in the James Webb Space Telescope - NASA's successor to the Huble telescope launching in 2018.

Each day in December, we'll publish a new video revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people.

snippet.title: Liz Bonnin - Beryllium and the James Webb Space Telescope

snippet.description:
The Ri caught up with presenter Dara O Briain on the set of Science Club to hear why he is such a fan of the group of elements known as the Alkali Metals. It might have something to do with Group 1's explosive reputation.

Each day in December, we'll publish a new video revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people.

snippet.description:
UCL Chemist Andrea Sella picks two elements that combine to form the compound didymium. This material is used by glassblowers in the lenses of their safety glasses because it absorbs the light from the sodium flares given off by hot glass.

snippet.title: Andrea Sella - Glassblowing and Didymium Glasses

snippet.description:
From the roof of the Ri, Derek Muller from the Veritasium YouTube channel stresses the need to communicate the beauty and importance of science. This 'element of truth' is vital to our understanding of how the world works and our place within it.

Check out the Veritasium Channel http://www.youtube.com/user/1veritasium

Each day in December, we'll publish a new video revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people.

snippet.description:
For the final film in our advent series, the 2012 Christmas Lecturer, Dr Peter Wothers, travels to the Sheffield University MRI Unit at the Royal Hallamshire Hospital to explore how the strange properties of his favourite chemical element are being used to image living lungs.

In the build up to this year's Christmas Lectures, we've published a new video for every day of advent revealing the elements that really excite and inspire people. 

The Ri is on Twitter: http://twitter.com/ri_science

snippet.title: Dr Peter Wothers - Using Xenon to Image Living Lungs
